author: @AlexxiiMain
text:
Man, what a tragic misfire. The Electric State had the potential to be something truly special, something quiet, melancholic, and deeply atmospheric, just like Simon Stålenhag’s original work. But instead of embracing the eerie stillness and emotional weight of the source material, Netflix chose to turn it into yet another action-heavy, color-graded spectacle that completely misses the point.

The original Electric State isn’t just a story, it’s an experience. It’s about silence, decay, and a world collapsing not with a bang, but with a whisper. Stålenhag’s art doesn’t need explosions or forced tension to be haunting, it’s haunting because of its restraint. The film, on the other hand, takes all that subtlety and throws it out the window. Instead of a meditative journey through a dying world, we get... well, just another generic sci-fi blockbuster.

And the worst part? This wasn’t inevitable. It was a choice. A choice to prioritize spectacle over substance. A choice to cater to the lowest common denominator instead of trusting the audience to appreciate nuance. A choice to take something unique and make it marketable instead of meaningful. And what makes it even more frustrating is that we know it could’ve been done right, because Tales from the Loop proved it. That series took another one of Stålenhag’s works and adapted it with care, with artistic integrity, and with the emotional depth it deserved. So the argument that The Electric State was “too difficult” to adapt properly? That’s just not true. It could’ve been done. They just didn’t want to.

What we got isn’t just a disappointing adaptation, it’s a perfect example of how Hollywood strips art of its soul in favor of engagement metrics and broad appeal. And in doing so, they didn’t just make a bad movie. They erased something beautiful.
The Russo Brothers should be removed from Hollywood, for commiting such an act of disrespect.

author: @wraith313

author: @EvanSquaredson
text:
Ugh. I've loved much of the Russo Brothers' work since seeing it in Community (Winter Soldier's my favorite Marvel movie, by a long shot), with their deft combination of character, action, and wit. And I fell in love with Simon Stålenhag's work since I first stumbled across a painting of his. But this is the precise opposite of the vibe I get from Stålenhag's imagery. I adore how Stålenhag depicts a sense of loneliness, the wan Scandinavian light, the commonplace acceptance of imagery that in another illustrator's work would evoke naive awe.

Tales From The Loop actually managed to capture some of that Stålenhag vibe; this trailer feels profoundly false and glib, a bad joke. It's not so much peanut butter and chocolate, as aquavit and Marshmallow fluff. Honestly, I wish both the Russo Brothers and Stålenhag great success at everything they do, but I also wish the two had never met, based on this.

author: @Severian1
text:
A book that is a gradual, haunting meditation on our growing meshing with technology, and societal collapse is turned into this travesty.

Among the sea of generic slop out there this could have been something unique. Why butcher something this unique over and over again? There’s a huge market for contemplative movies and complex sci-fi. Why aren’t they being satisfied?
